item.title: welcome to my site!
item.content:encoded:
welcome to my site!

if you know me in real life, you know that i continue to espouse the sentiment that i am finishing up my portfolio site. well, that's sort of the case..... i decided to revamp it through hosting it on github pages again. while i liked the ease of use of adobe portfolio, the features were not conducive to where i wanted to take my site and would often leave me too frustrated to be motivated to make it work.

marcinek.tech is not just a portfolio site, but it is also a page where one can glimpse into more personal interests of mine. you may see this as a mistake, and that is valid, but i often denote the idea of "personal" vs "professional" to be too rigid of boundaries. the phrase "be the change you want to see in the world" comes to mind. if i don't act in such a way that (respectfully) pushes the barriers of social norms, who am i to complain about them?

a major inspiration for the direction of this site came from friends and colleagues whom i have met in person who are also interested in creative technology. likewise, the web revival and indieweb movements are of great interest to me. i won't reveal the url, but i was a rather early adopter of neocities! lastly, i have been going through mark fisher's k-punk archives as well as the wit of the staircase by theresa duncan. two geniuses in their respective disciplines gone too soon, both with blogs a part of their legacies.

on this site, you will see an archive of some of my best and/or favorite works in game design, computational art, and immersive media. this site is my portfolio first and foremost. most of the other topics on here are related to my professional interests. this blog won't be about the meals i had today, for example. i also feel the need to reiterate my footer disclaimer: while i am proud of, grateful for, and identify with my employment history, all thoughts and opinions expressed are my own. they are not representative of the wilson center, national children's museum, american university, or rutgers university.

a core tenet of mine is there is something to be learned from everyone. i write not as an authority, but as an equal. this is not to say i have no expertise on the matters i write about, quite the opposite, nor is it an excuse for me to portray narratives that are uninformed. rather, it is a reminder that the lens in which i write is ultimately just that of another person. a valuable lens, a lens which attempts to ground itself in tangible realities outside of me, but still my own, not free from bias or egocentrism.

i hope you enjoy your stay! this website is currently still under construction. i am having some continued issues with using the bootstrap 5 stylesheet. you may also click on a lot of dead or broken links. adding more things as i go!

memento vivere,

kristen 💌

item.title: ANNOUNCEMENT: find me at mlk library for my maker talk, games are for everybody!
item.content:encoded:
ANNOUNCEMENT: find me at mlk library for my maker talk, games are for everybody!

DATE: saturday july 20th @ 1 pm to 2 pm

REGISTER IN-PERSON OR FIND THE YOUTUBE LINK HERE

hello everyone! i just wanted to announce that on saturday july 20th, 2024 at 1 to 2 pm, i will be giving a maker talk at the mlk jr memorial library in washington dc titled games are for everybody!

part introductory primer on the game design & development process, part discussion about representation in and accessibility of games, i will be pulling from my professional game design experience as well as teachings from some of my favorite professors.

hope to see everybody there!

memento vivere,

kristen 💌

item.title: connecting intriguing theory and practice
item.content:encoded:
connecting intriguing theory and practice

what are the common themes in inspiration for my work?

2024-07-06

mind map created in miro

recently, i have been indulging in a lot of research around social theory to inform my praxis and practice. while much of my focus has been on topics that i've engaged with prior, i wanted to dive more deeply to create a personal framework of expertise.

the topics i am currently surrounding myself with include ludology, marxism, playful design, nostalgia, cyberfeminism, absurdism, existentialism, and surrealism. all topics one may think have little in common. in a lot of my research, it has come to light to me that it is quite the contrary, and thus, the map above was born.

through reading mary flanagan's essay "locating play and politics: real world games & activism" this past semester, i have come rather enamored not just with the idea of pervasive games, immersion & physicality, and stretching the boundaries of the magic circle, but with an unexpected, briefly discussed portion of this article: situationist international and guy debord.

mark fisher is a rather hot name amongst gen z social theorists - for good reason. his expansion of hauntology resonates with the recent y2k-era (late 90s to early 2010s) nostalgia many 20-somethings are facing right now. finding mark fisher's involvement with sadie plant, who like mary flanagan conducts research on cyberfeminism and situationist international, was rather intriguing. from what i have found so far, sadie plant and mary flanagan have not had any direct collaboration, though.

like jean-paul sartre and his attempts to rectify marxist ideals with existentialist beliefs, i often find myself grappling with similar. can certain schools of thought coexist, or further, inform one another? many marxists believe existentialism is inherently incompatible with marxism. like sartre, i must disagree, and i think situationist international and their absurdist motifs may disagree as well. the lack of an ability to rectify the differences is an interesting line of thinking to consider given that marx was majorly influenced by hegel, whose dialectics have proven to be paramount to my readings of philosophy, at least.

what do you think of my connections? am i sensing patterns where patterns may not belong?

memento vivere,

kristen 💌

item.title: recent press (+ a fundraiser!)
item.content:encoded:
recent press (+ a fundraiser!)

2024-07-09

okay, maybe press is too official of a word, here. maybe this should actually be titled "recent features." regardless of the title, i thought i would round up some happenings from my life!

volunteering for metfest 2024

check out the article, "met fest and youth gamers: creating wider trajectories at the local level" by my professor ben stokes on his blog for the playful city lab!

my work with the serious games initiative

being the production office assistant for the short film the audition

check out the fundraiser for continuing the production of the audition on indiegogo!

link to post

shout-out by american university career center

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by AU Career Center (@aucareercenter)

feature on 84hashi's social media

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by 84staff (@84.hashi)

full disclosure: speaking about my accomplishments is always a very strange thing for me to balance properly. often, i find myself not wanting to accidentally come off as arrogant so much that i simply do not really mention what goes on in my life. perhaps a bad approach, especially because when i do tell people about myself or my work, it tends to be surprising. maybe a list format doesn't help the "bomb drop" approach!

likewise, there is the possibility i should worry less about coming off as arrogant. all i can do is try my best to be my authentic self; that's all we can ask of anyone.

memento vivere,

kristen 💌

item.title: dialectics
item.content:encoded:
dialectics

holding space for our own multitudes as well as turmoil....and realizing where our big heads stem from

2024-07-10

vulnerability

i think the world would be better if we allowed each other space for open dialogue. what could be imagined, even accomplished, if we not only didn't shame others, but also didn't shame ourselves?

this piece of creative non-fiction, titled "dialectics," comes from my archive of writings. definitely a more vulnerable piece of work. it also happens to be one of my favorites. it has a less "academic" context attached to it than most of my other writings here will have.

hegelian dialectics are paramount for my understanding of the world. it is interwoven within the fabric of existence; there is too much complexity in the world for absolute, innate truth to exist. hope you enjoy!

1966: First view of Earth from the moon (Luna Orbiter 1) sourced from NASA/LOIRP

i find myself caught within the crossfire of two persistent truths.

my gram once told me, “the most intelligent people are the saddest, and there was a sadness in you that i felt deeply.” i often regard myself as someone whose eyes are open to the world and its horrors, and i don’t know if i can ever go back. the world is brimming with sorrow. how can i not see it? how can i not feel it?

yet in me i find the optimist. the person my mom would always quip that “she never cried when she fell.” i’d simply get back up and try walking again. i’d never go back to just crawling like the other babies. the person who laughs at her own jokes so hard she can never just spit them out, who adores saturation and vibrancy.

can these two truths coexist in some twisted semblance of harmony? or will they always be battling to defeat each other, one eventually succeeding with the other lost to time, only existing in a former self?

i consider that maybe they stem from the same virtue. could it be that the world is just so beautiful, and i see so much opportunity for everyone and everything? i often denote these truths as my curse—but i know i do not genuinely believe that—i’d take this battle of truths over blissful ignorance in every lifetime.

Base explanation of Hegel’s Dialectics sourced from the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy

is this piece a plea for understanding? is it too self-congratulatory? well, if we take my own mindset into consideration, these interpretations can co-exist. thank you for reading.

memento vivere,

kristen 💌

item.title: potpourri no.1
item.content:encoded:
potpourri no.1

mind stuff

2024-07-12

originally, this series of posts was going to be titled "hamster food." why? i took inspiration from this meme pictured below. these posts are truly just my mind's stuff, much like hamster food is just stuff.

wise words from tiktok user big beluga

"hamster food" didn't seem to fit quite right, though. i have a tote bag, gifted to me by my grandma, that i carry around with me often. i have given her the name "potpourri." this name was given for similar reasons why i would name this "hamster food." she (potpourri, my tote bag) is full of stuff that makes me happy, inspired by the fact that potpourri is really just stuff that smells good. i have decided to adopt this name for these posts as well.

"potpourri" is a round up of stuff going on in my life as well as stuff in the world i find fascinating and worth to share. i want to put out a new "potpourri" weekly, but this may change based on my bandwidth. truly, speaking about my life's happenings and my interests is something i find very challenging. therefore, i hope you find value in the stuff shared here!


creatin'

presentations

i made an announcement about one of my presentations in a separate blog post, but i am now giving TWO presentations in ONE weekend!

i am very excited and honored to have been chosen to speak about some of the stuff i make. i am currently in "finishing up presentations" mode, which has taken up most of my recent time.

queer joy jam: polly heart, mall mop

alongside the presentations, i have been working with some friends on making a submission for the queer joy jam!

our idea is titled "polly heart: mall mop." it is a 2d sidescroller where you play as a queer character who tries to shoplift the most joyous and affirming outfit you can from the mall. alongside the stealth element of the sidescroller, players can play dress up with some of the clothes from their heist at the end of the game!

clown egg

it was exciting to find out that the clowns international egg registry does not need one to be of active clown status to submit to them. you just need a unique clown persona to submit pictures of and pay a membership fee.

i have now made it my mission to be able to confidently say that i have a registered clown egg. i am creating a clown persona inspired by 90s whimsigoth aesthetics. it is currently a work in progress, you can see a very rough sketch here. my tentative clown name is twinkles. :)

you are so loved.

i think often of those who feel lost in this world. maybe as you read this, you think this is crazy, but i wish i could tell these people that the world loves them. i love them, and that they are needed. i have never once thought that the scarcity of love is what makes it meaningful. i feel like love just pours out of my heart, and i need somewhere to express it. what better way to send my message than through a love letter to the masses?

"you are so loved" is a love letter inspired augmented reality project i am currently working on. it is rather simple in its implementation; i will be posting the above qr code as a sticker that links to a subpage of my website which depicts a 3d model of the message that i created with blender. i am in the midst of making sure the model formats well to all screens as well as polishing the front-end.


evanescent interests

  • barbie liberation organization
  • crip time
  • the navy's sea lions love video games
  • pinecil

moodboard

godzilla vs hedorah poster, polish ver.

knowmad by mel chin

find more here

[domestic] by mary flanagan

find more here

smiling friends


🌱 sprouts from my mind garden

what is intelligence if not just efficiency?

there are many ways the word "intelligence" is defined, and many different contexts for its use exist. when i ponder on what intelligence is, really, my context is the rudimentary concept of being "smarter than."

if two people can solve the same math problem with the same accuracy, but one finishes it faster than the other, the one who finishes faster would commonly be regarded as "smarter." why, though? at the end of the day, they both finished the problem correctly. therefore, does the swiftness in which one solves a problem have weight on how intelligent they are? does this not indicate that intelligence in the end is not just efficiency?

this is something i would like to explore further. i am sure there must be others who have not only asked this question, but answered it. this truly exists as a sprout, currently. i wonder about a world where "intelligence" may be interpreted differently without the context of capitalism and its unrealistic hyper-focus on human productivity.

10 year gamergate retrospective

this august will be 10 years from the beginnings of the gamergate saga. gamergate started when i was 14, and it subsequently "ended" when i was about 15 or 16. a child, really. i was incredibly passionate about speaking out against gamergate and in support of the likes of zoe quinn and anita sarkeesian, especially. gamergate had a significant impact on my worldview at the time; so much so that i presented a research poster on it for a community college anthropology course i was taking my junior year of high school.

a post coming up soon will be a retrospective on the sociopolitical landscape in games at that time through my now 24 year old, more educated perspective. i will also be releasing a review of the game that (kind of, sort of) started it all, depression quest.

the faux tension of empathy and sympathy

i often find the debate surrounding the meaningfulness of sympathy vs empathy, and especially the opinion that empathy is inherently more meaningful, to be too black and white. something i ponder on is, is empathy not just heightened centering of the self? is it not more brave to admit to someone you have no idea what they're going through, no way of feeling what they are feeling, yet you still feel for them? how exactly can one discern the difference between feeling for someone opposed to feeling with someone, and why do we perceive one as more empty, and often further, more condescending, than the other? are we not creating a dichotomy where one does not need to exist? this is an idea i want to explore further, especially within the context of empathy-fueled serious games. if anyone has recommendations for literature on this, please feel free to share! i want to gather informed perspectives wherever i can.


consumin'

  • playing: depression quest (watch out for a review!)
  • viewing: godzilla (1954) at the theater tomorrow
  • listening: menstrual tramps (who played near where i live not too long ago)

memento vivere,

kristen 💌
